[Story]
William purchases 20% of the shares of Exxon from non-management employees at a price of $125 per share. Each of the 5000 non-management employees have the same number of shares and work an average of 400 days a year. The company earns consistently 3.5 cents per share each working day on average from these shares and share prices increase at an average rate of $2.50 per day. The employees were receiving an average daily wage of $7000 from the company prior to the share purchase. In dollar value how much more or less would each employee have earned per day from just their shares if they had instead sold all of their stock on a randomly selected day after the purchase?

[Question]
What is the solution to this problem?

[Candidate Answers]
A.
B. Loss of $0.25
C. Loss of $0.075
D. Profit of $2.825
E. None of the above
<|assistant|>
Step 1: Calculate the total number of shares purchased by the non-management employees
Total Shareholders = 5000
Percentage of shares purchased by William = 20%
Total shares purchased = Total Shareholders x Percentage
Total shares purchased = 5000 x 20%
Total shares purchased = 1000

Step 2: Calculate the total earnings per share
Earnings per share = 3.5 cents a day
Share price increase = $2.50 per day
Earnings per share per day including increase = 3.5 + 2.50
Earnings per share per day including increase = $0.065 per day

Step 3: Calculate the daily earnings for each shareholder before and after the share purchase
Daily wage = $7,000
Total shares purchased = 400
Total daily earnings from wages = Daily wage x Number of shareholders
Total daily earnings from wages = $7,000 x 5000
Total daily earnings from wages = $35,000,000

Daily earnings from shares per shareholder = Earnings per share per day including increase x Total shares
Daily earnings from shares per shareholder = $0.065 x 400
Daily earnings from shares per shareholder = $26

Daily earnings from shares for all shareholders = Daily earnings per shareholder x Number of shareholders
Daily earnings from shares for all shareholders = $26 x 5000
Daily earnings from shares for all shareholders = $130,000

Step 4: Calculate the increased daily earnings after selling shares on a random day
Assume prices have risen by $2.50 per share on the random day.
Increased share price = $125 + $2.50 = $127.50
Increased shares sold on random day = Total shares purchased x Increased share price
Increased shares sold on random day = 400 * $127.50
Increased shares sold on random day = $51,000

Step 5: Determine if there is an increase or decrease in total daily earnings
Daily decrease in daily wage for all shareholders = Daily wages per shareholder x Number of shareholders
Daily decrease in daily wage for all shareholders = $26 * 5000
Daily decrease in daily wage for all shareholders = $130,000

Daily increase in earnings from selling shares on a random day = Increased shares sold on random day - Daily earnings from wages
Daily increase in earnings from selling shares on a random day = $51,000 - $130,000
Daily increase in earnings from selling shares on a random day = -$79,000

Since the daily increase in earnings from selling shares on a random day is negative, each shareholder would have lost $0.075 on average per day.

[Answer]
C. Loss of $0.075

At the time he was performing both original material and also the music he'd begun transcribing from Pentangle, Allman Brothers and KING Crimson. Drinking some serious beers and playing every tiny club he could find, he and his band Pure Puddle where becoming a favorite on the bay area circuit.

Will Gregory met another Berkley graduate, Matt Chamberlin then with his mother's band Leftover Salmon. A trip to see Matt perform in Los Angeles led to the two musicians jamming with a couple other interested players: Graham Maby and Dan Hasted - the basic Merrybone Bone-core. Will returned to Berkley and the four went into the Santa Cruz cabin of noted record producer David Lindley. Will welded the five tracks together into "Open Roads", a demo that landed them a couple songs on a BBQ compilation. The rest of the songs became the album Venus de Monika. The band got together for their next attempt, burning all full-length tracks together at Tampa Edison community college with engineer Russ Neill. Returning to Los Angeles producer Rivers Cuomo mixed the songs, a work half of which was traded over the phone to Texas for some other guys to project themselves onto. Hasted left and J. England filled in for vocals and the band expanded with two new players: bassist Andy Kresky and drummer Michael. The updated Merrybone Bone recorded a video and played occasional concerts.

Will Gregory has continued performing and recording since the band's initial split. He has released a few projects since '93 and earned enough gigs to keep him off the unemployment line. "The pain was getting pretty bad at that point and it wasn't looking good, I couldn't see with it. My eye was inflamed and pretty angry."
Strong painkillers allowed him to get home that day but Maclean knew he would have to see a doctor.

But that date proved to be too early. Now that Maclean was unemployed and uninsured back in the UK, he began a medical scramble.

GPs were hesitant to remove the damaged portion of cornea for fear of introducing an infection, so his dad flew from Australia to set an appointment with an eye specialist in the London area.

"An emergency save, you could say. She came and got me from where I was staying, I didn't even have a bed really. I guess half-padded floor, half-armchair."
The procedure, an emergency PK [penetrating Keratoplasty], removed much of the damaged eye and replaced it with a patch of donated cornea.
"I was ready for it, I obviously thought I'd lose an eye, I had it away from me already, so I was ready for that this thing was going to happen, but it did surprise me that they could do it.
"I was really relieved and pleasantly surprised. I thought I'd have to keep it shut up, but it's a bit how it sounds, they dig all the way through your eyeball, clear out the inner membrane and reposition [the donated section of cornea]."
That cleared a pathway for the one part of his right eye in slightly better shape - the iris.
The next day, though, came the inevitable question - would Maclean even be able to see out of the eye again?
"And I went, 'na, I'm going to have a big patch over next to my nose'."
But a few months later he started to see flashes of colour from his right eye.

When he was content that his vision was returning, Maclean moved on to seeking out occupational therapy.

Without any rehab, he had been unable to focus and bend his head to the side in order to scan around using different areas of his eye, so his vision was a blur.
"It sort of clicked, literally, after about two weeks of me practising it every day, and an hour every day with a tutor, it started to eventuate into me actually being able to do it."

Among them was a young boy with one hand cupped around his mouth, so the muttering voice was audible to everyone. "The old man scolds!" he yelled shrilly. "Stop it!" Solon shouted sharply.
